text: Could we prevent this by allowing people who want to have their registries be public submit a list of "we've reserved the following UUIDs" to General? Attackers then have to convince victims to install an additional registry, right?

elements.text: Could we prevent this by allowing people who want to have their registries be public submit a list of "we've reserved the following UUIDs" to General? Attackers then have to convince victims to install an additional registry, right?

text: I fear this would lead to organizations saying "ok, we're going to need... right about 1000 UUIDs. And 1000 more next week."

elements.text: I fear this would lead to organizations saying "ok, we're going to need... right about 1000 UUIDs. And 1000 more next week."

text: The problem also isn't necessarily limited to other public registries - it can also occur with just one private registry and General, where a malicious package in General shadows the "true" package in the private registry. An individual `]add` ing the "private" package may be tricked into installing the malicious package (with no warning) because of the shadowing and the higher version of the malicious package

elements.text: The problem also isn't necessarily limited to other public registries - it can also occur with just one private registry and General, where a malicious package in General shadows the "true" package in the private registry. An individual
ing the "private" package may be tricked into installing the malicious package (with no warning) because of the shadowing and the higher version of the malicious package

text: Well, the good thing about UUIDs is that they are many of them :stuck_out_tongue:

elements.text: Well, the good thing about UUIDs is that they are many of them
